CHIN 1.title: Elementary Modern Chinese
CHIN 1.description: The beginning course in Chinese. The student acquires a basic knowledge of the grammar, a limited general vocabulary, correct pronunciation, and an ability to read and understand simple texts. Weekly laboratory assignments support and enhance classroom learning.

CHIN 1NH.title: First Year Chinese Heritage
CHIN 1NH.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chinese 1N.
CHIN 1NH.description: Intended for Chinese heritage speakers who wish to learn to read and write Chinese. Content is similar to Chinese 1 with less emphasis on developing  oral skills.

CHIN 2NH.title: First Year Chinese Heritage
CHIN 2NH.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chinese 2N.

CHIN 3NH.title: First Year Chinese Heritage
CHIN 3NH.comments: Not open to students who have completed Chinese 3N.

CHIN 5NH.title: Second Year Chinese Heritage
CHIN 5NH.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Chinese 5N.

CHIN 8A.title: Chinese Conversation
CHIN 8A.description: The course is designed to increase facility and naturalness of delivery in simple dialogue. This course is designed for the students who have finished first year Chinese.

CHIN 8B.title: Chinese Conversation
CHIN 8B.description: The course is designed to increase facility and naturalness of delivery in simple dialogue.

CHIN 26.title: New Phenomena in 21st Century Chinese
CHIN 26.description: The Chinese language today consists of a number of new words, phrases and expressions from languages such as English and Japanese. This course is to explore the contact and its impact on Chinese language and society in the 21st century.

CHIN 32.title: Contemporary Chinese Religions
CHIN 32.description: Examines Chinese popular religion, Daoism, Buddhism, Confucianism,   Christianity, and Islam as shaped and transformed by revolution and  nationalism, and the recent rapid commercialization, urbanization, and globalization of China. Religiosity and changing notions of self,    family, gender, community, and citizenship.

CHIN 35.title: Introduction to Taiwan Literature
CHIN 35.description: Provides basic introduction to the historical background and major writers of Taiwan literature in its development since the 19th century. Topics: sociopolitical and cultural changes, literary trends and writing characteristics from the Japanese colonial period to the present.

CHIN 40.title: Popular Culture in Modern Chinese Societies
CHIN 40.description: Provides an overview of Chinese popular culture in China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong. From fiction to film, music to MTV, and from cartoons to Karaoke, this course proves the popular as it has manifested itself in the modern Chinese societies.

CHIN 48.title: Self, Society, and Nature in Chinese Thought
CHIN 48.description: A look at how major thinkers in classical Chinese thought grappled with questions related to the individual's place in society and their relationship to their environment. Highlighting their relevance, classical views will be applied to contemporary ethical, social, and environmental debates.

CHIN 80.title: Masterpieces in Chinese Literature
CHIN 80.description: Examines a selection of works from Chinese literature, with the goal of understanding the major genres and their development over time. The cultural roles of literature, as well as criteria for critical evaluation, are also addressed.

CHIN W 80.title: Masterpieces in Chinese Literature
CHIN W 80.description: Examines a selection of works from Chinese literature, with the goal of understanding the major genres and their development over time. The cultural roles of literature, as well as criteria for critical evaluation, are also addressed.

CHIN 82.title: Modern Chinese Literature
CHIN 82.description: This course, taught in English, surveys an archive of seminal short fiction, novellas, novels, and poems that tell the story of China and the Chinese from the end of the Qing dynasty to the present. What has been the place of literature in China in the modern era? What vision of modern China do we find in its literature? How, moreover, does literature subvert the national narrative? Through literature as a window on the history of modern China, students will gain a better understanding of Chinese history and culture with regard to its social reform, revolution, war, cultural revolution, cultural revival, and economic growth.

CHIN 90AAZZ.title: Topics on China
CHIN 90AAZZ.description: Introduction to an aspect of China i.e., culture, history. Contact   Department of East Asian Languages and Culture for the specific topic.

CHIN 99.title: Independent Study in Chinese
CHIN 99.comments: Students must have a cumulative 3.0 for the proceeding 1 quarter(s).   Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA. Limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
CHIN 99.description: Introduction to independent research in Chinese.  Topic and content are  decided by the supervising Professor in the Department of East Asian Languages and Cultural Studies.

CHIN 99RA.title: Independent Research Assistance in Chinese
CHIN 99RA.comments: Students must have a cumulative 3.0 for the proceeding 1 quarter(s).   Students must have a cumulative 3.0 GPA for the preceding 1 quarter.   Students are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all  98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
CHIN 99RA.description: Research details are decided by the supervising Professor in the   Department of East Asian Languages and Cultural Studies.

CHIN 101A.title: Introduction to Classical Chinese
CHIN 101A.description: The grammar and vocabulary of classical Chinese. Readings concentrate on philosophical and historical works from the pre-Han period, with some selections from later prose and poetry. Students with some familiarity with Chinese characters (through another Asian language) but not modern Chinese will be accommodated.

CHIN 101B.title: Introduction to Classical Chinese
CHIN 101B.description: The grammar and vocabulary of classical Chinese. Readings concentrate on philosophical and historical works from the Pre-Han period, with some  selections from later prose and poetry. Students with some familiarity with Chinese characters (through another Asian language) but not   modern Chinese will be accommodated.

CHIN 101C.title: Introduction to Classical Chinese
CHIN 101C.description: The grammar and vocabulary of classical Chinese. Readings concentrate on philosophical and historical works from the Pre-Han period, with some selections from later prose and poetry. Students with some familiarity with Chinese characters (through another Asian language) but not modern Chinese will be accommodated.

CHIN 102.title: Chin 102: Advanced Chinese Conversation
CHIN 102.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Summer, Fall.
CHIN 102.description: Designed to further develop an intermediate to high level and put emphasis on spoken language competence within situations such as work places or in social activities.

CHIN 103.title: Reading and Writing in Chinese
CHIN 103.description: Designed to enhance reading and writing skills in Chinese for students who have finished second year Chinese.

CHIN 104.title: The Buddhist Influence on Chinese Language and Culture
CHIN 104.prereq_description: Upper division standing or instructor approval
CHIN 104.description: Exploratory study of non-Chinese influences on Chinese language and culture as demonstrated by the language of Buddhist sutras translated into Chinese.

CHIN 105.title: Workshop in Chinese Translation
CHIN 105.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
CHIN 105.description: Practical work in translation from a variet of Chinese sources depending onneed. Emphasis on accuracy and rigor.

CHIN 106A.title: Seminar in Chinese Literary Translation
CHIN 106A.description: Designed to introduce various approaches to translation, especially the techniques of translating literary works from Chinese into English. Published translation texts are provided as the main vehicle for the analysis and discussion of translation problems in order to learn and develop practical skills of translation.

CHIN 106B.title: Seminar in Chinese Literary Translation
CHIN 106B.description: Designed to introduce various approaches to translation, especially the techniques of translating literary works from Chinese into English. Published translation texts are provided as the main vehicle for the analysis and discussion of translation problems in order to learn and develop practical skills of translation.

CHIN 115A.title: Imagism, Haiku, and Chinese Poetry
CHIN 115A.description: A comprehensive study of the nature and principles of the haiku and of classical Chinese poetry, their influence on the western imagists, and the theoretical and experimental achievements of the major imagist poets in thedevelopment of modern English poetry. Taught in English.

CHIN 116.title: Survey on World Literatures in Chinese
CHIN 116.description: Focus on analyzing literary works in Chinese from China, Taiwan, Hong Kong,Southeast Asia, America, and Europe as a comprehensive survey of the worldwide modern literature of Chinese diaspora.

CHIN 121.title: Seminar on Taiwan Literature
CHIN 121.prereq_description: Upper division and Chinese 6 or instructor approval
CHIN 121.description: Focus on major issues of Taiwan literature from Japanese occupation (1895-1945) to the present with regard to the interaction of Taiwan's native cultures, China's grand tradition and foreign influences during the historical development.

CHIN 122A.title: Advanced Modern Chinese
CHIN 122A.description: Advanced practice in grammar and composition.

CHIN 122B.title: Advanced Modern Chinese
CHIN 122B.description: Advanced practice in grammar and composition.

CHIN 122C.title: Advanced Modern Chinese
CHIN 122C.description: Advanced practice in grammar and composition.

CHIN 124A.title: Readings in Modern Chinese Literature
CHIN 124A.description: Advanced readings in the Chinese language in fiction, drama, and poetry written after 1919. Designed for students with advanced Chinese background.

CHIN 124B.title: Readings in Modern Chinese Literature
CHIN 124B.description: Advanced readings in the Chinese language in fiction, drama, and poetry written after 1919. Designed for students with advanced Chinese background.

CHIN 125.title: Business Chinese
CHIN 125.description: A course intended to equip the properly qualified student to conduct business in modern Chinese. Emphasis will be placed on using appropriate vocabulary in realistic situations.

CHIN 126A.title: Advanced Readings in Taiwan Literature
CHIN 126A.description: A selection of texts in Chinese by representative authors; literature during the Japanese rule (1895-1945). Designed for advanced students to gain an overall view of achievements of major writers in different genres.

CHIN 126B.title: Advanced Readings in Taiwan Literature
CHIN 126B.description: A selection of texts in Chinese by representative authors; works after WW II to the present. Designed for advanced students to gain an overall view of achievements of major writers in different genres.

CHIN 127A.title: Fourth Year Chinese
CHIN 127A.description: Course series for students who have completed third year Chinese. Extensive reading and discussion of colloquial versus formal usage of Chinese are the major focus of the course.

CHIN 127B.title: Fourth Year Chinese
CHIN 127B.description: Course series for students who have completed third-year Chinese. Extensive reading and discussion of colloquial versus formal usage of Chinese are the major focus of the course.

CHIN 127C.title: Fourth Year Chinese
CHIN 127C.description: Course series for students who have completed third-year Chinese. Extensive reading and discussion of colloquial versus formal usage of Chinese are the major focus of the course.

CHIN 132B.title: Special Topics in Modern Chinese Poetry
CHIN 132B.description: Topics focus on major trends of modern poetry developed in mainland China and Taiwan with particular attention to romanticism, realism, and modernismafter contact with the West. Readings in Chinese, lectures and discussions in English.

CHIN 134D.title: Art and Modern China
CHIN 134D.comments: ARTHI 134D is the same course as CHIN 134D.

CHIN 134K.title: Chinese Calligraphy- History and Aesthetics
CHIN 134K.description: Examines the different scripts in historical context, surveys significant movements and artists, and considers the ideas, theories and aesthetic principles that have enriched the art of writing to elite status in China.

CHIN 136.title: Advanced Readings in Vernacular Literature
CHIN 136.description: Readings in novels of the Ming and Ch'ing periods.

CHIN 138A.title: Special Topics in Taiwan Studies - Humanities
CHIN 138A.description: Special topics in Taiwan studies with respect to literature, history, and culture from the period of Japanese rule (1895-1945) to the present, including modernity, national identity, intellectual movements, and popular culture.  Topics and reads will vary with instructors.

CHIN 138B.title: Special Topics in Taiwan Studies - Social Science
CHIN 138B.description: Special topics in Taiwan studies with respect to historical, economic, political, cultural, and social changes in Taiwan from the period of Japanese rule (1895-1945) to the present.  Topics and readings will vary with instructors.

CHIN 139.title: China in Translation: Theory, Art, History
CHIN 139.description: Uses the case study of translations into and out of China- long regarded as a civilization distinct from west- to explore themes in translation studies. Topics: ideograms, orientalism, modernization, world literature, annotations, musicality, poetic license, adaptation.

CHIN 140.title: Tang Literary History
CHIN 140.description: Examines the history of literature during the celebrated Tang dynasty (618-907). Focus on changes in literary norms, practices, and theory as they intersected with societal, political, intellectual, and religious developments. Also considers problems of historiography. Emphasis varies by quarter.

CHIN 143.title: Urban Legends:  Traditional Chinese Stories and Their Afterlives
CHIN 143.prereq_description: upper division standing or instructor approval
CHIN 143.description: Masterworks of fiction from the Ming and Qing periods as products of urban culture in late imperial and contemporary China.  Stories by Feng Menglong, Li Yu, tales by Pu Songling, and excerpts from classic novels.

CHIN 144.title: Women Writers of Late Imperial China
CHIN 144.description: A study of Chinese women writers in the late imperial period (roughly 1500-1900), a newly rediscovered part of China's literary history.  Examination of their personal lives and writings in relation to the Chinese literary tradition, women's history and feminist criticism.

CHIN 146.title: Poetic Culture in late Imperial China and Beyond
CHIN 146.description: An examination of the role poetry played in both social and individual lives in late imperial China, with particular attention to self-expression and literary community.  Relevant practices in later times and in Japan and Korea are also covered.

CHIN 163A.title: Sex, Drugs, and Chinese Meditation
CHIN 163A.description: Charts the development of alchemy in China, from its origins as a laboratory science devoted to the compounding of elixirs of immortality to its later incarnations as a Buddhist and Daoist process of self-cultivation.

CHIN 163B.title: Chinese Martial Arts Through Film
CHIN 163B.prereq_description: One course in humanities or social science
CHIN 163B.description: Examines how the medium of film is employed in forging an image of Chinese culture as "martial" and "spiritual." Examples from Hong Kong, mainland Chinese, and American cinema are considered.

CHIN 166C.title: Confucian Traditions: The Classical Period
CHIN 166C.description: A treatment of the origins of Confucianism and of its development through the Han Dynasty (to A.D.200), with special attention to the variety of humane and spiritual disciplines which came to be called "Confucian." Emphasis on the interpretation of primmary texts like the Analects, the Mencius, the Hsun Tzu, etc.

CHIN 167.title: Queer China, Crip China
CHIN 167.description: In this course we study the representation of non-normative bodyminds and desires (e.g. disability and homosexuality) in modern Chinese literature and film. We discuss the meanings embedded in Chinese discourses of gender, sexuality, and disability; investigate how these discourses have been appropriated in the construction of a modern Chinese national identity; and connect our specific inquiry into Queer China and Crip China to our general attempt to answer the broader question of how the modern nation-state "China" has been imagined into being over the past century. Our approach is interdisciplinary, comparative, and transnational.

CHIN 170.title: New Taiwan Cinema
CHIN 170.description: Critical survey of the new Taiwan cinema (1982-86) movement and its representative filmmakers Edward Yang and Hou Hsiao-hsien. Works by other contemporary directors such as Tsai Ming-liang, and Chen Kuo-fu are also analyzed.

CHIN 172.title: Fiction and Film in Contemporary China
CHIN 172.description: Presents a critical historical overview of Chinese literature and film from 1949 to the present. In addition to writers and filmmakers from mainland China such as Mo Yan and Zhang Yimou, course considers literary and cinematic development from Hong Kong, Taiwan, and the Chinese diaspora.

CHIN 174.title: Hong Kong Cinema
CHIN 174.description: A critical survey of contemporary Hong Kong cinema, including introduction to major movements (i.e., the Hong Kong New Wave), genres (martial arts, horror, melodrama), and filmmakers. Equal attention will be paid to analysis, film history, and historical/cultural context.

CHIN 175.title: Chinese Masters
CHIN 175.description: Focus on the work of a single contemporary Chinese Writer, artist, or filmmaker, providing an in-depth analysis of his/her body of work. May include Zhang Yimou, Jiz Zhangke, Mo Yan, Wang Anyi, and Hou Hsiao-hsien, among others.

CHIN 176.title: Chinese Cinema: Nationalism and Globalism
CHIN 176.prereq_description: upper division standing or instructor approval
CHIN 176.description: A critical overview of some of the major cinematic trends in Chinese-language film over the past several decades. Works from the PRC, Taiwan and Hong Kong, as well as Chinese cinema will be considered in a global context.

CHIN 180AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Chinese Studies
CHIN 180AAZZ.description: Special topics in Chinese Studies. Course content varies.

CHIN 183A.title: Chinese Popular Religion
CHIN 183A.description: Course covers a variety of Chinese popular religions from an anthropological perspective. Readings will be ethnographies of modern China, Taiwan, and late imperial histories. Shamanism; Fengshi/geomancy; ancestor and deity worship; millenarianism; popular Christianity; pilgrimage; syncretism with Daoism, Buddhism, Confucianism.

CHIN 183B.title: Religious Practice and the State in China
CHIN 183B.description: Historical and anthropological approaches to the interaction between religious practice and state forces, with emphasis on popular religion and the decline and revival of religion in Chinese modernity.

CHIN 184A.title: History of China
CHIN 184A.prereq_description: History 2A or 2B or 2C or 80, or EACS 80, or upper-division standing.
CHIN 184A.comments: Same course as History 184A. Not open for credit to students who have completed Chinese 186A or History 186A.
CHIN 184A.description: History of China. Ancient China to 589 CE.

CHIN 184B.title: History of China
CHIN 184B.prereq_description: History 2A or 2B or 2C or 80, or EACS 80, or upper-division standing.
CHIN 184B.comments: Same course as History 184B. Not open for credit to students who have completed Chinese 186B or History 186B.
CHIN 184B.description: History of China. Sixth to seventeenth centuries.

CHIN 184T.title: History of Traditional Chinese Thought
CHIN 184T.comments: Same course as History 184T. Not open for credit to students who have completed History 190C.
CHIN 184T.description: A study of traditional Chinese thought from the classical period to the beginning of the last imperial dynasty (500 BCE -1700 CE).

CHIN 185A.title: Qing Empire
CHIN 185A.prereq_description: A prior course in History or upper-division standing.

CHIN 185B.title: Modern China (since 1911)
CHIN 185B.prereq_description: Any lower-division course in History or upper-division standing.
CHIN 185B.description: The fall of the dynastic system, the revolution against traditional  values, the rise of the Nationalist Party, the challenge from the    Communists, the founding of the People's Republic, and the Post-Mao  reform, with a focus on the theme of revolution.

CHIN 185R.title: Undergrad Research Seminar on Modern China
CHIN 185R.prereq_description: History 185A or 185B or Chin 185A or Chin 185B or HIST 185CQ or CHIN 185CQ and upper division standing.
CHIN 185R.description: Research seminar in the history of modern China. Students will conduct historical research in a seminar context, using both primary and secondary source materials, to produce an original and substantial research paper.

CHIN 185T.title: History of Modern Chinese Thought
CHIN 185T.prereq_description: HIST 2A-B-C or HIST 80 or HIST/CHIN 184A-B or HIST/CHIN 185A-B or EACS 4A-B
CHIN 185T.comments: HIST 185T is the same course as CHIN 185T.
CHIN 185T.description: Leads students to understand some of the most important ideas, theories, and concepts in Modern China.

CHIN 185CQ.title: Reading Seminar on the Chinese Cultural Revolution (1966-1976)
CHIN 185CQ.prereq_description: History 2C or 80 or 184A or 184B or 185A or 185B or EACS 4A or EACS 4B or  Chin 184A or Chin 184B or Chin 185A or Chin 185B
CHIN 185CQ.comments: Misc: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
CHIN 185CQ.description: No understanding of contemporary China is possible without understanding the ramifications of the Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution. This   course seeks to consider the tumultuous episode as a field of historical research and conceptual inquiry. We create this class together.

CHIN 185CR.title: Reading Seminar on the Chinese Cultural Revolution (1966-  1976)
CHIN 185CR.description: An understanding of contemporary China is not possible without understanding the ramifications of the Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution (1966-1976). We will examine the nature of China's Cultural Revolution, its beginning and ending, and how ordinary Chinese people experienced this tumultuous episode in history.

CHIN 188A.title: History of Women in China: From the Ancient Period to the Nineteenth Century
CHIN 188A.description: Exploration of the diverse roles women have played in Chinese culture and society up to the 19th century by examining the many contexts within which women operated: the family, the imperial court, literati and popular culture.

CHIN 197.title: Senior Honors Project
CHIN 197.prereq_description: Open to senior majors only; consent of instructor.
CHIN 197.comments: Students must have a 3.0 overall grade-point average and a 3.5 grade-point average in the major.
CHIN 197.description: An independent study course (1 to 3 quarters) directed by a faculty member with a carefully chosen topic and bibliography which will result in a  documented project or a senior thesis.

CHIN 198.title: Readings in Chinese
CHIN 198.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Chinese.
CHIN 198.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the preceding three quarters and  are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all     98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined. May be repeated up to 12 units.

CHIN 199.title: Independent Studies in Chinese
CHIN 199.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Chinese major; Minimum major GPA of 3.5 or higher
CHIN 199.comments: Students must have a 3.0 cumulative GPA for the preceding 3 quarters and are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all     98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
CHIN 199.description: Independent studies in Chinese. Individual investigations in literary  fields.

CHIN 201.title: Readings in Selected Texts
CHIN 201.prereq_description: Ability to read Chinese at graduate level; consent of instructor.
CHIN 201.description: Course will center on readings of Chinese texts; type and period to depend on needs of students and wishes of instructor. Research methods to be  taught as appropriate.

CHIN 204.title: The Buddhist Influence on Chinese Language and Culture
CHIN 204.description: Exploratory study of non-Chinese influences on Chinese language and culture as demonstrated by the language of Buddhist sutras translated into Chinese.

CHIN 205.title: Workshop in Chinese Translation
CHIN 205.description: Practical work in translation from a variety of Chinese sources depending on need. Emphasis on accuracy and rigor.

CHIN 210.title: Research Seminar in Taiwan Studies
CHIN 210.description: Research seminar on major issues in Taiwan studies with introduction to bibliographies, reference works, and research methodologies. Under the guidance of a faculty member, students will undertake independent research and work on a research project of their own.

CHIN 211.title: Bibliography and Research Methodology
CHIN 211.description: Introduction to the bibliography, reference works, and methodologies of  sinological research.

CHIN 220.title: Topics in Tang Literature
CHIN 220.description: Explores themes and issues in the literature of the Tang dynasty, with an emphasis on close reading and translation of original texts in Classical Chinese. Topical focus varies.

CHIN 221.title: Seminar on Taiwan Literature
CHIN 221.description: Focus on major issues of Taiwan literature from Japanese occupation (1895-1945) to the present with regard to the interaction of Taiwan's native cultures, China's grand tradition, and foreign influences during thehistorical development.

CHIN 231.title: Imagining Atrocity in Modern Chinese Literature and Film
CHIN 231.prereq_description: Open to graduate students and advanced undergraduates with the instructor'spermission. All students should have reading proficiency in Chinese.
CHIN 231.description: An examination of how atrocity and mass violence have been revisited, reimagined, and reconstructed by modern and contemporary writers and filmakers. Major incidents to be considered include the Nanjing Masacre, the February 28, 1947 incident in Taipei, Taiwan, and the Cultural Revolution.

CHIN 238A.title: Special Topics in Taiwan Studies - Humanities
CHIN 238A.comments:
Concurrently offered with Chin 138A.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit in the major to a maximum of 8 units providing topics are different.
CHIN 238A.description: Special topics in Taiwan studies with respect to literature, history, and culture from the period of Japanese rules (1895-1945) to the present, including modernity, national identity, intellectual movements, and popular culture. Topics and readings will vary with instructors.

CHIN 238B.title: Special Topics in Taiwan Studies - Social Science
CHIN 238B.comments:
Concurrently offered with CHIN 138B.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit in the major to a maximum of 8 units providing topics are different.
CHIN 238B.description: Special topics in Taiwan Studies with respect to historical, economic, political, cultural, and social changes in Taiwan from the period of Japanese rule (1895-1945) to the present.  Topics and readings will vary with instructors.

CHIN 245.title: Gender and Expression in Pre-Modern Chinese Literature
CHIN 245.description: This graduate seminar examines Chinese literary tradition from the   perspective of gender, discussing the gendering of new modes of expression in de/constructing men and women as social categories over the long course of Chinese literary history.  Discussion and readings are mainly in    English (and Chinese, depending on the backgrounds of students).

CHIN 246.title: Poetic Culture in Late Imperial China and Beyond
CHIN 246.description: An examination of the role poetry played in both social and individual   lives in late imperial China. Relevant practices in later times and in   Japan and Korea are also covered.  Graduate student paper is required.

CHIN 247.title: New Directions in Chinese Literary and Cultural Studies
CHIN 247.description: This seminar discusses research methods and critical concepts emergent in the most recent studies of Chinese literature and culture. Concentrating on the 16th to the 20th centuries, it is intended to bridge studies of pre-modern and modern periods.

CHIN 249.title: Literati Culture
CHIN 249.description: A study of literati (Wen-ren) culture of the middle period concentrating onthe Sung Dynasty. Attention to developments in literature, historiography, the visual arts, and philosophy. Readings (in Chinese and English) from Sudongpo, Li Qingzhao, Sima Guang, and Zhu Xi.

CHIN 249A.title: Literati Culture
CHIN 249A.description: Exploration of literati cultures of Tang and Song dynasties.  Topical focus varies.

CHIN 249B.title: Literati Culture
CHIN 249B.description: Exploration of literati culture of Tang and Song dynastices.  Topical focus varies.

CHIN 250.title: The Language of Vernacular Chinese Literature
CHIN 250.description: Early Mandarin as represented in selections from vernacular Chinese fictionof the sixteenth through eighteenth centuries. Primarily concerned with the syntactical and semantic features employed in the reading selections but will also consider the issue of literary expression.

CHIN 251.title: Chinese Language Pedagogy
CHIN 251.description: Introduces students to currrent issues in Chinese language instruction and trains them to become full-fledged Chinese language specialists. Includes an introduction to Chinese linguistics and course-related designs involved in language teaching.

CHIN 252.title: Pedagogical Chinese Grammar
CHIN 252.description: Provides an overview of Chinese grammar and focuses on  topics relevant to the CFL teacher. It also analyses inter-language  errors in the Chinese learners. Graduate students should apply a  theoretical edge to syntactic phenomena in presentations and papers.

CHIN 253.title: Introduction to Historical Chinese Syntax
CHIN 253.description: Aims to provide students with opportunities to explore and examine the mechanisms and the motivations of syntactic change in Chinese in 3rd c BC- 21st century. Readings and paper requirements for graduate students are more extensive.

CHIN 255.title: The Role of Language Contact in the History of Chinese Language
CHIN 255.description: A survey of language contact types and mechanisms and its impact on Chinese language development from the third century to present time.

CHIN 260.title: Readings in Taoism
CHIN 260.comments:
Same course as RG ST 260.
Repeat Comments: Course content variable; may be repeated for credit.
CHIN 260.description: Selected readings from important Taoist texts.  Depending on the year, primary sources will be read in original Chinese or in translation.
CHIN 260.recommended_prep: One year of formal study of classical Chinese.

CHIN 262.title: Science and Medicine in Medieval China
CHIN 262.prereq_description: Basic Classical Chinese or Kanbun required.
CHIN 262.description: This course undertakes a critical history of science and medicine in premodern China, focusing primarily on their role as instigators of interchange between Buddhism, Daoism, and various intellectual currents.

CHIN 264.title: China in the World
CHIN 264.description: Investigates the histories and theories of World Literature as a world-making ideology and as a discipline in literary studies. Particularly, it participates in current debates on globalization and cosmopolitanism by focusing on the case of modern Chinese literature and culture.

CHIN 266F.title: Readings in Chinese Buddhism
CHIN 266F.comments:
Same course as RG ST 266F.
Repeat Comments: Course content variable; may be repeated for credit.
CHIN 266F.description: Selected readings in important Buddhist texts which were either    originally written in Chinese or translated into that language.    Depending on the year, primary sources will be read in original Chinese  or in translation.
CHIN 266F.recommended_prep: One year of formal study of classical Chinese.

CHIN 267.title: Queer China, Crip China
CHIN 267.description: Study of the representation of non-normative bodyminds and desires (e.g. disability and homosexuality) in modern Chinese literature and film. We discuss the meanings embedded in Chinese discourses of gender, sexuality, and disability; investigate how these discourses have been appropriated in the construction of a modern Chinese national identity; and connect our specific inquiry into Queer China and Crip China to our general attempt to answer the broader question of how the modern nation-state ?China? has been imagined into being over the past century. Our approach will be interdisciplinary, comparative, and transnational.

CHIN 270.title: New Taiwan Cinema
CHIN 270.description: Critical survey of the new Taiwan cinema (1982-86) movement and its representative filmmakers Edward Yang and Hou Hsiao-Hsien. Emphasis on cinema history, formal film analysis, and introduction to the major thematic concerns of Taiwan film and media culture.

CHIN 274.title: Hong Kong Cinema
CHIN 274.comments:
Concurrent with CHIN 174. Graduate students will have extended meeting times, additional readings, and a longer seminar paper.
Repeat Comments: Topics vary; may be repeated for credit.
CHIN 274.description: Critical survey of contemporary Hong Kong cinema, including introduction to major movements (i.e. the Hong Kong New Wave), genres (martial arts, horror, melodrama), and filmmakers. Equal attention will be paid to analysis, film, history, and historical/cultural context.

CHIN 275.title: Chinese Masters
CHIN 275.comments:
Concurrent with CHIN 175. Graduate students will have extended meeting times, additional readings, and a longer seminar paper.
Repeat Comments: Topics vary; may be repeated for credit.
CHIN 275.description: Focus on the work of a single contemporary Chinese writer, artist, or  filmmaker, providing an in-depth analysis of his/her body of work.  May  include Zhang Yimou, Jiz Zhangke, Mo Yan, Wang Anyi, and Hou     Hsiao-hsien, among others.

CHIN 285.title: Graduate Research Seminar on Modern China
CHIN 285.description: Research seminar in the history of modern China. Students conduct historical research in a seminar contact using both primary and secondary source materials, to produce an original and substantial research paper. Graduate students will receive extra readings from their instructor and will complete a longer research paper at the end of the course.

CHIN 285CR.title: Reading Seminar on the Chinese Cultural Revolution (1966-1976)
CHIN 285CR.comments: Concurrent with CHIN 185CR.  Graduate students will be assigned longer papers.
CHIN 285CR.description: An understanding of contemporary China is not possible without understanding the ramifications of the Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution (1966-1976).  We will examine the nature of China's Cultural Revolution, its beginning and ending, and how ordinary Chinese people experienced this tumultuous episode in history.
